statement.tex: %text Find the differential equation representing the curve \[ y = cx + c^2 \] %

step.context:
\textbf{A theoretical question} %text
Would we be right if we said the following about $y=cx+c^2$?
step.tex: %text $y = cx+c^2$ has no $\frac{dy}{dx}, \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2}$ or $\left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^2$ type terms. Hence, it is an equation - but not a differential equation. %

%text This is a trick question.
\[ y = cx + c^2\] is both an equation \underline\text{and} a differential equation. %
step.reason:
%text A differential equation - by definition - expresses the relationship between a variable and its derivatives $\left[ \frac{dy}{dx}, \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2}\text{ etc.} \right]$
$y=cx +c^2$ has no such derivative terms. Hence, it is not a differential equation. %

step.context: %text Given what a differential equation is, which of the following differential equations represents $y = cx + c^2$? %
step.reason:
%text \underline\text{If you differentiated $y=cx+c^2$ twice} to get \[ \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} = 0\], then here is the issue
% \begin{align} \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} &= 0 \implies \frac{dy}{dx} = c \text{ (a constant)}\\ \therefore y &= cx + D \end{align} %text
But $D$ \underline\text{need not be } equal to $c^2$ - as is required in $y = cx + c^2$.
To meet all conditions, one must therefore do the following
%
\begin{align} y = cx + c^2 &\implies \frac{dy}{dx} = c \\ \therefore y &= \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right) x + \left( \frac{dy}{dx} \right)^2 \\ \text{or } \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right) x &+ \left( \frac{dy}{dx} \right)^2 - y = 0 \end{align}
